headline: US could seek piece of defense companies, Commerce chief says
summary: STORY: The Trump administration is considering taking stakes in defense companies and other firms it does business with, including Lockheed Martin and Boeing.That's according to U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, who told CNBC on Tuesday he believes talks are needed around how the government finances its munitions acquisitions, as he defended President Donald Trump's push for a greater government role in American business.Lutnick said Pentagon officials are considering taking pieces of government contractors, including AI powerhouse Palantir Technologies.Boeing declined to comment, and representatives from Lockheed and Palantir did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Lutnick's comments came a day after President Trump said he wants to make more government investments in American companies...having already announced a near-10% stake in Intel and revenue-sharing deals with fellow chipmakers Nvidia and AMD.But critics warn this change could potentially impede these companies' independence, said Liz Miller, president of Summit Place Financial Advisors."If President Trump starts this, and promises no interaction, that doesn't tell us at all what future presidents might do."Shares of Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Palantir Technologies were all higher in Tuesday morning trading.

raw.headline: US could seek piece of defense companies, Commerce chief says
raw.summary: STORY: The Trump administration is considering taking stakes in defense companies and other firms it does business with, including Lockheed Martin and Boeing.That's according to U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, who told CNBC on Tuesday he believes talks are needed around how the government finances its munitions acquisitions, as he defended President Donald Trump's push for a greater government role in American business.Lutnick said Pentagon officials are considering taking pieces of government contractors, including AI powerhouse Palantir Technologies.Boeing declined to comment, and representatives from Lockheed and Palantir did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Lutnick's comments came a day after President Trump said he wants to make more government investments in American companies...having already announced a near-10% stake in Intel and revenue-sharing deals with fellow chipmakers Nvidia and AMD.But critics warn this change could potentially impede these companies' independence, said Liz Miller, president of Summit Place Financial Advisors."If President Trump starts this, and promises no interaction, that doesn't tell us at all what future presidents might do."Shares of Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Palantir Technologies were all higher in Tuesday morning trading.

headline: Lutnick: Defense Contracting Has 'Been a Giveaway'
summary: The Trump administration is reviewing how the U.S. works with defense contractors, according to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick on Tuesday.  "There's a monstrous discussion about defense," Lutnick said in a CNBC interview, when pressed on whether defense companies could be next for a U.S. government stake.  Lutnick also said that if companies come to President Trump and want government help with a business transaction, especially with foreign countries, the president may propose a stake in the company in exchange for assistance.

raw.headline: Lutnick: Defense Contracting Has 'Been a Giveaway'
raw.summary: The Trump administration is reviewing how the U.S. works with defense contractors, according to Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick on Tuesday.  "There's a monstrous discussion about defense," Lutnick said in a CNBC interview, when pressed on whether defense companies could be next for a U.S. government stake.  Lutnick also said that if companies come to President Trump and want government help with a business transaction, especially with foreign countries, the president may propose a stake in the company in exchange for assistance.

headline: 'Deal-based capitalism' is 'quite problematic': Larry Summers
summary: The US government has taken a 10% stake in Intel (INTC), a deal that President Trump has signaled could be the first of a new norm. Former US Treasury Secretary for the Clinton administration, Larry Summers, who also sits on the OpenAI (OPAI.PVT) board of directors, joins Opening Bid to weigh in on the deal and its implications. Watch Yahoo Finance's full interview with the former Treasury secretary. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: Tech Weekly: Intel's activist investor, Google's new salesman
summary: STORY: From how Intel got a pushy new shareholder, to why Google recruited Jimmy Fallon, this is Tech Weekly.++++Intel has a prominent new investor.Donald Trump confirmed that Washington would take a 10% stake following talks with company chief Lip-Bu Tan.“And I said, you know what? I think the United States should be given 10% of Intel."Analysts debated whether the move was a welcome boost for the ailing chipmaker… or a worrying sign of government meddling in business.++++Google showed off its latest phones, with help from talk show host Jimmy Fallon.Analysts say the Pixel handsets offered relatively modest upgrades over previous models.But the tech giant was keen to tout advances on AI.That includes a “coach” in the camera app that can help users take better pictures.++++Nvidia boss Jensen Huang says he wants to weigh up China demand before making more chips for the country:"We've prepared a lot of H20 already, but now we are waiting for purchase orders from China customers and so when we receive the orders, we will be able to produce more."Reports have claimed that Nvidia is developing an advanced new chip for the country, but Huang stressed that it was up to Washington what products it could ship to Beijing.++++Amazon could switch to using the regular Android operating system for its Fire tablets.The firm currently uses its own custom version, but has faced gripes from consumers over shortcomings including a very limited app store.Now Reuters sources say Amazon could release higher-end tablets as soon as next year, though they say that’s likely to mean a price hike over current models.++++And Apple could use Google’s Gemini to revamp Siri.Bloomberg News says the AI model could be used to power the voice assistant.Neither firm would comment, but the report comes after Apple delayed rolling out an AI version of Siri.It’s lagging rivals like Samsung in incorporating the tech into its smartphones.

raw.headline: Tech Weekly: Intel's activist investor, Google's new salesman
raw.summary: STORY: From how Intel got a pushy new shareholder, to why Google recruited Jimmy Fallon, this is Tech Weekly.++++Intel has a prominent new investor.Donald Trump confirmed that Washington would take a 10% stake following talks with company chief Lip-Bu Tan.“And I said, you know what? I think the United States should be given 10% of Intel."Analysts debated whether the move was a welcome boost for the ailing chipmaker… or a worrying sign of government meddling in business.++++Google showed off its latest phones, with help from talk show host Jimmy Fallon.Analysts say the Pixel handsets offered relatively modest upgrades over previous models.But the tech giant was keen to tout advances on AI.That includes a “coach” in the camera app that can help users take better pictures.++++Nvidia boss Jensen Huang says he wants to weigh up China demand before making more chips for the country:"We've prepared a lot of H20 already, but now we are waiting for purchase orders from China customers and so when we receive the orders, we will be able to produce more."Reports have claimed that Nvidia is developing an advanced new chip for the country, but Huang stressed that it was up to Washington what products it could ship to Beijing.++++Amazon could switch to using the regular Android operating system for its Fire tablets.The firm currently uses its own custom version, but has faced gripes from consumers over shortcomings including a very limited app store.Now Reuters sources say Amazon could release higher-end tablets as soon as next year, though they say that’s likely to mean a price hike over current models.++++And Apple could use Google’s Gemini to revamp Siri.Bloomberg News says the AI model could be used to power the voice assistant.Neither firm would comment, but the report comes after Apple delayed rolling out an AI version of Siri.It’s lagging rivals like Samsung in incorporating the tech into its smartphones.

headline: Heard on the Street Monday Recap: Trump’s New Deal
summary: President Trump said he wants to pursue more deals like the government’s equity investment in Intel.  The U.S. converted funds previously allocated for manufacturing expansion into a 9.9% stake in the chip maker.  The government also obtained a five-year warrant, under which it could receive an additional 5% if Intel spins out or sells off its manufacturing operations.

raw.headline: Heard on the Street Monday Recap: Trump’s New Deal
raw.summary: President Trump said he wants to pursue more deals like the government’s equity investment in Intel.  The U.S. converted funds previously allocated for manufacturing expansion into a 9.9% stake in the chip maker.  The government also obtained a five-year warrant, under which it could receive an additional 5% if Intel spins out or sells off its manufacturing operations.
